reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The food in general was good. We had the Mediterranean night buffet at dinner and it was somewhat mixed. Much of the food in fact is not Mediterranean at all (e.g Chinese fried rice, lamb kebabs, tiny burgers in a pasty brown gravy, and several other main items. There were some nice grilled chicken and succulent hammour fish on the buffet. What Med country services hot dog stir fry?. There was nothing on the dessert buffet that could be called Mediterranean with the possible exception of a well prepared crème brulee. A strawberry cheesecake type concoction was clearly made largely from packaged non-dairy whipped topping, whose primary ingredient is vegetable oil, mixed with a little gelatin---it bore no relation to cheesecake as we know it and left a nasty greasy aftertaste on the tongue. Some mini pate choux éclair were nicely done. The idea of these internationally themed evening buffets is good for family-style resorts such as those on the Dead Sea but seem out of synch with the Asian inspired minimalist design of the complex. And for JD 30++ per head the buffet needs to be truly special and was not. Others have commented to us about the ersatz Indian and Mexican themed buffets, and one can just imagine what they must be like -- the credibility of a hotel like this should be marked by authenticity and creative use of local ingredients. The bottom line is that you should offer what you can execute well. The breakfast was fine, nothing great, but adequate. We were impressed by the quality of the fresh fruit on the buffet, obviously these were all hand selected.
reviews.title: Lovely escape
Refinement with mixed success
reviews.text: The spa facilities were OK. Although we did not have time for a special treatment, we found the pools generally OK. A facility advertising itself as a spa needs to offer better features. The large swimming pool was nice but was like every other swimming pool-- the warm water pool was OK, though inadequately maintained and the furniture and surround were very scruffy---the resort it cries out for special water features such as those one can find at the Zara spa at the Movenpick Dead Sea hotel just a few miles away: e.g. massaging jets of water of varying strengths and velocity. The men's changing room was converted from a set of toilet stalls and like much of the resort, could benefit from much better maintenance - it does not take much effort to retile and paint the stalls so one does not feel like he is changing in an old toilet. Still, one felt in awe of swimming in the pool while staring up at the dramatic rock landscape and imagining the Ma'in oasis must have been like 2000 years ago by earlier visitors.

One can tell that the kindness of the staff member was not just part of their jobs, but was instilled in them to comfort the customers to their maximum satisfaction!
